texts.shortText: Forms tangled masses of unattached, dark-green, slender, branched filaments, each composed of a row of cylindrical cells placed end to end. Stiff and often curled and may form clumps, or be entangled among other algae.
Filaments about 0.25-0.3 mm wide, can be extremely long, up to at least 500 mm.

Global: Very widespread across temperate and tropical seas.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to northern KwaZulu-Natal.

Common in sheltered sites, such as harbours and estuaries, but also tidal swimming pools, where the photographed specimen was found. Unattached and often curled around the stipes of other algae to maintain position. Stiff and hard to the touch.

Show alternating generations - the asexual, diploid sporophyte produces numerous spores which develop into haploid (having only one set of chromosomes) male and female gametophytes, which in this case are morphologically indistinguishable from the sporophyte. These produce sperm and eggs which fuse and develop back into sporophytes. Also reproduce asexually by fragmentation of the clump.

Some sources consider the attached and unattached forms as both being varieties of C. linum, but this seems extremely unlikely, as they differ greatly in both form and habitat. Thus we follow both Algaebase and the local west and south coast guides listed below, in retaining them as distinct species and terming the attached form C. aerea.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 374).

Stegenga, H, Bolton, J & Anderson, R (1997). Seaweeds of the South African west coast. Contributions of the Bolus Herbarium, 18. (p. 101).
